description.plain: Be Sweet is the second track on Japanese Breakfast’s third full-length album. It is happy and upbeat when it is first listened to, but after looking more closely at the lyrics, there is a dark side. In this song, Michelle sings directly to a significant other, mentioning fantasies of her lover leaving her, and asks them to make up for the lies that they have told her.

song.title: Be Sweet

body.plain: Be Sweet is the second track on Japanese Breakfast’s third full-length album. It is happy and upbeat when it is first listened to, but after looking more closely at the lyrics, there is a dark side. In this song, Michelle sings directly to a significant other, mentioning fantasies of her lover leaving her, and asks them to make up for the lies that they have told her.

songs.full_title: Be Sweet - Spotify Singles by Japanese Breakfast
songs.title: Be Sweet - Spotify Singles

annotations: Make it up once more with feeling

This is a reference to the musical episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Season 6, Episode 7: “Once More, With Feeling,” when the characters are forced to reveal their innermost feelings in song. The episode title comes from the lyric: “All those secrets / You’ve been concealing / Say you’re happy now, / Once more with feeling.”
Chorus

About the chorus, Michelle Zauner said:

It’s probably the most chorus I’ve ever written
Fantasize you’ve left me behind and I’m turned back running for you

This may be related to a line from “Posing for Cars”, suggesting that her partner leaving her might be a recurring theme in her conscious and subconscious thoughts:

Woke from a dream in which you’d left me

Make it up to me, you know it’s better
 Make it up to me, you know it’s better
Michelle expresses a longing to mend a broken relationship by asking her partner to make up for his/her past mistakes, as they both know it’d serve both parties for the better

description.plain:
“Posing in Bondage” sees Michelle Zauner asking for connection, or “bondage.” The title is purposefully misleading, leading the listener to assume she will discuss sexual bondage.

Zauner said of the song:

This song is about the bondage of controlled desire, and the bondage of monogamy—but in a good way.

The original version of this track was released on Zauner’s 2017 Polyvinyl 4-Track Singles Series. A reproduced version appeared on her 2021 album Jubilee.

A video released on April 8, 2021. Zaunder described the MV as an epilogue to the later music video for “Savage Good Boy”.

body.plain:
“Posing in Bondage” sees Michelle Zauner asking for connection, or “bondage.” The title is purposefully misleading, leading the listener to assume she will discuss sexual bondage.

Zauner said of the song:

This song is about the bondage of controlled desire, and the bondage of monogamy—but in a good way.

The original version of this track was released on Zauner’s 2017 Polyvinyl 4-Track Singles Series. A reproduced version appeared on her 2021 album Jubilee.

A video released on April 8, 2021. Zaunder described the MV as an epilogue to the later music video for “Savage Good Boy”.

annotations: All of the nights you turned away my touch

this line may suggest the singers desperation for her partners touch, as referred to in the next few lines, “proximity, closeness, i needed, bondage”.

it could also reference the fact that perhaps the singer is not that physically affectionate and the one time she gets “done up and drunk”, or the time when she is finally ready to be more affectionate, she is ignored by her partner, thus making her desire for their love more extreme.
I hope you come home soon

this line could reference the idea that the singer is stuck in her place and unable to get out of something without assistance. perhaps the bondage could be a reference to being tied down or into her relationship, and the only one who is able to untie her is her partner, hence why she hopes they will come home soon, because she has been posing of ‘hours’ and is desperate to escape the bondage.
Bondage

In this context, bondage can be taken literally, like a woman dressed in bondage waiting for someone to come home to such a sexual display. There is also the symbolic meaning behind monogamy, in which humans seek the comfort that bondage in monogamy can provide.

When the world divides into two people
 Those who have felt pain
 And those who have yet to
Rather than simply saying, “There are people who’ve felt pain, and people who haven’t,” Zauner opts for a more poignant statement by implying that everybody feels pain, eventually.
Can you tell I’ve been posing

Posing in this context suggests faking or pretending as a way to cover up Michelle’s true feelings for someone. She asks if this person can see through her veil and recognize her true affection for this other person.

description.plain:
This breezy, serene ballad with orchestration that channels Brian Wilson features Michelle singing about the sweet loneliness of teenage love, waiting for your crush to return. Incidentally, Kokomo is also a Beach Boys' song about two lovers enjoying a relaxing vacation in Kokomo island in the Caribbeans, as a form of escapism.

https://giphy.com/gifs/realspaceforce-netflix-space-force-is-a-joke-homNAGPTzSltisqnyI

Here, the song’s subject’s crush left their home town (presumably Kokomo, Indiana)  to pursue their dreams (“showing off to the world the parts I fell so hard for”), while the subject stayed, passing time and “popping wheelies”, feeling lonely and empty, wishing they could go back to a time when they were with each other. Michelle seems to be playing with the titles of the songs, creating a contrast between Kokomo, IN, a place to escape from; and Kokomo Island, a place to escape to.

song.title: Kokomo, IN

body.plain:
This breezy, serene ballad with orchestration that channels Brian Wilson features Michelle singing about the sweet loneliness of teenage love, waiting for your crush to return. Incidentally, Kokomo is also a Beach Boys' song about two lovers enjoying a relaxing vacation in Kokomo island in the Caribbeans, as a form of escapism.

https://giphy.com/gifs/realspaceforce-netflix-space-force-is-a-joke-homNAGPTzSltisqnyI

Here, the song’s subject’s crush left their home town (presumably Kokomo, Indiana)  to pursue their dreams (“showing off to the world the parts I fell so hard for”), while the subject stayed, passing time and “popping wheelies”, feeling lonely and empty, wishing they could go back to a time when they were with each other. Michelle seems to be playing with the titles of the songs, creating a contrast between Kokomo, IN, a place to escape from; and Kokomo Island, a place to escape to.

annotations: You know that I’ll be here always
Her ex knows that she is still longing for them, they always will, and they can always return to her.

I know they deserve you too
 And maybe I’m not that worthy
She feels she’s not worthy of her ex’s love no matter how hard she tries to win it back or no matter how hard she wants it back. She feels others deserve her ex partner more than she does.
Flyover state
People don’t often visit Indiana but rather fly over it to reach another destination.

If ever you come back
 Wherever you find your way to
 And though it may not last
 Just know that I’ll be here longing

She will always be waiting for them, no matter what they have done or how long they have been gone. This reminds me of the “Last Christmas” by Wham! lyric:
“Now I know what a fool I’ve been
But if you kissed me now, I know you’d fool me again”

If I could throw my arms around you
 For just another day
 Maybe it’d feel like the first time
 Now that you’re away
 I’ll just spend my life not knowing
 How it’d feel to

She’s been away from her ex-partner so long that she believes she’s forgotten how it’d feel to hold them, making it feel like the first time again if only she could hold them. But she will spend the rest of her life not knowing what it would feel like to hold the new version of them that has been born since their break up.
Popping wheelies

Popping wheelies means to perform a manoeuvre on a bicycle, motorcycle, or other vehicle in which one travels forward with the front wheel(s) raised up and the rear wheel(s) remaining on the ground.

This line alludes to some imagery of skateboarding or BMX specifically; the feeling of being lost in a suburb in a somewhat desolate town, with a very physical activity being the only solace away from that. The next line furthers this interpretation, as well as the phrasing possibly being a metaphor for pushing or doing tricks on a skateboard.

All of this gives us a picture very reminiscent of 80’s and 90’s culture, when freestyle street skating was first taking off, with Rodney Mullen at the helm of it all. This connection is furthered by the song only mentioning ever having a physical connection with this unspoken love of the narrator. The internet was still a work-in-progress with its development in the world, and a town of ~45,000 at that time wouldn’t be likely to initially use it for things like IM, and MySpace wouldn’t be developed for another couple decades, depending on the timeframe you’re working with.
Manifesting like the fear of an oven left on

An oven left on is a fire hazard, and Zauner is using this as a metaphor for her life: manifesting her own desire and fantasy that will prove catastrophic for her mindset in the long term, like an oven being left on.
Watching you show off to the world the parts I fell so hard for
In an interview with James Rettig on Sterogum, Michelle expressed how much she loved this particular line, and how it would’ve been so nice if you were a teenager and someone said that to you.

description.plain:
As Michelle Zauner revealed in an interview with NPR,

The song title comes from this Satoshi Kon movie, Paprika, and this sort of surreal parade that happens. I was playing around with a lot of these Spitfire Albion orchestra plugins, and I had come up with this marching band thing that built up into this huge crash in the chorus.

song.embed_content: Read “Paprika” by Japanese Breakfast on Genius
song.title: Paprika

body.plain:
As Michelle Zauner revealed in an interview with NPR,

The song title comes from this Satoshi Kon movie, Paprika, and this sort of surreal parade that happens. I was playing around with a lot of these Spitfire Albion orchestra plugins, and I had come up with this marching band thing that built up into this huge crash in the chorus.

annotations: I awoke from dreams of untying a great knot
“Tying the knot” is a phrase meaning getting married, potentially this is a metaphor for divorce as the knot is being untied by the narrator.

Oh, it’s a rush
 Oh, it’s a rush

The sonic shift from previous albums Psychopomp and Soft Sounds from Another Planet is remarkably evident in the opener “Paprika” which bubbles with excitement and euphoria, the equivalent of waking up full of energy to a brand new day (after having a dream of “untying a great knot”).

With Zauner  singing “it’s a rush!” with the help of a carefully pop-curated horn and string arrangement, the feelings of loss and grief from previous albums, although still there, are evolving into something that can allow joy as well. She told Harper’s Bazaar:

I think we went into the third album just wanting to be confident and bombastic and ambitious and almost theatrical. We had a large palette to pull from; nothing was limited. And so I think that the arrangements are larger, they’re warmer, they’re more vibrant, there are more strings and horns. I’m always just chasing this kind of lift in music. And I felt much more comfortable and confident using different types of instruments to get there.

How’s it feel to be at the center of magic
 To linger in tones and words?
 I opened the floodgates and found
 No water, no current, no river, no rush
 How’s it feel to stand at the height of your powers
 To captivate every heart?
 Projecting your visions to strangers
 Who feel it, who listen to linger on every word

Zauner expresses her excitement about being a musical artist and being able to connect with fans who “linger on every word” she puts in her lyrics. She told Esquire:

I’ve always felt like I needed to experience some type of anguish in order to feel productive as an artist. ‘Paprika’ is a reminder to recognize you’re in this really enviable position of being a professional artist and to relish in that.

Here, finding “no water, no current, no river, no rush” is symbolic of Zauner stepping away from the more melancholy tones of her past work as she finds appreciation for and joy in everything around her. “Water” may also be a literal reference to tears, which she sees less of now that she’s changing her mindset.

The “height of [her] powers” references the success Zauner has found and the subsequent joy she feels from finally making it. She also touches on these feelings on “Jimmy Fallon Big!” and “Road Head.”

It’s also interesting to note the different between the “dry” first half of the chorus and the more passionate second half. When she asks herself how it feels to be able to create magic with music and lyrics, she feels nothing special. But, when she reframes the question and asks herself how it feels to have the power to connect so strongly with “strangers,” she feels an intense rush. She feels much more from touching her audience with her music than she does when appreciating her craft in solitude.

description.plain: The second single off of “Soft Sounds From Another Planet” is the second cover of the song “Day 6,” originally found on the Japanese Breakfast album “June.” The song later reappeared in a new form on Little Big League’s second LP as “Boyish.”

song.embed_content: Read “Boyish” by Japanese Breakfast on Genius
song.title: Boyish

album.full_title: Soft Sounds from Another Planet by Japanese Breakfast
album.name: Soft Sounds from Another Planet

body.plain: The second single off of “Soft Sounds From Another Planet” is the second cover of the song “Day 6,” originally found on the Japanese Breakfast album “June.” The song later reappeared in a new form on Little Big League’s second LP as “Boyish.”

annotations: What do you want from me?
Michelle sounds stressed whilst delivering this line, implying that she is tired of changing herself to please other men.
If you don’t like how I look, then leave

This line implies that Zauner struggles with insecurities.
It could also imply that a once insecure Zauner has over time become more confident in her looks and suggests that if he doesn’t like her for the way she is – he can leave.
And all of my devotion turns violent
She tries caring for the person she loves but always ends up having resentment or being upset with her lover from the lack of love she isnt getting back.
Lack of inhibition works wonders in revealing every demon

When people aren’t inhibited by their experiences,emotions or whatever may be holding them back, their true self comes out. That true is never perfect because as humans we are flawed, and thus along come the demons; our secrets,failures,struggles and pains.
If you go to her, don’t expect to come home to me

The words spoken are meant to be assertive and express that she is nobody’s second option. The line is beautiful, although the words are bullish, the intonation used is almost begging the boy to stay. The vocals begin aggressively and end with a whimper. It is almost as if she is trying to stand up for herself and be decisive, but she knows that she is more invested in the boy than he is in her.

I can’t get you off my mind
 I can’t get you off in general

The line not only reinforces the one-sided nature of the relationship (her mental preoccupation with the less than faithful man) but also introduces a feeling of sexual inadequacy (“can’t get you off in general”), further illustrative of a relationship gone awry.
I want you and you want something more beautiful

Michelle wants nothing more than to be in a committed relationship from her lover, but they can’t say the same about her.

This “something more beautiful” possibly references the “her” in Verse 1 and the hostess in Chorus 2.

Your boyish reassurance is not reassuring
 And I need it

Zauner is insecure about the relationship and looks to her lover for assurance that he loves her back, but to no avail. The use of “boyish” speaks to the immaturity and lack of commitment she feels from her lover.

On the later Soft Sounds track “Till Death,” she finds more comforting reassurance from someone else:

While the cruel men continue to win
You’d reassure me in a way you only can

As my ugly mouth kept running
 
 [Outro]
 Love me
 Love me

Depressed, the persona calls the other person’s attention to themself despite having self-esteem issues (“ugly”), as they seek to also be recognized.
This line contrasts the ones before it that talk of the person watching the lips of the hostess, which would infer that the crush is attracted to the hostess but not to the speaker. Essentially the speaker is saying, “You really think the waitress is attractive, wow I guess I’m just ugly.”

I can’t get you off my mind
 You can’t get yours off the hostess
 Watched her lips reserving tables

While the persona of this song looks at the object of his or her affection, they in turn look at a different person doing something totally ordinary. It reiterates the song’s undercurrent of unrequited love, that even while the persona is presumably looking affectionately askance, he or she is totally ignored by the object of his or her affection.

description.plain:
This song first appeared under the same name on the early Japanese Breakfast release American Sound.

On Soft Sounds from Another Planet, it has been given a full studio arrangement. Zauner stated in a tweet that the song was about someone who “told [her] that they didn’t think [she] was cut out for a music career.”

body.plain:
This song first appeared under the same name on the early Japanese Breakfast release American Sound.

On Soft Sounds from Another Planet, it has been given a full studio arrangement. Zauner stated in a tweet that the song was about someone who “told [her] that they didn’t think [she] was cut out for a music career.”

songs.full_title: Road Head (American Sound) by Japanese Breakfast
songs.title: Road Head (American Sound)

annotations:
“Dream on, baby,” were his last words to me
 “Dream on, baby”
 So dreaming baby took that corkscrewed highway

Michelle Zauner told NPR:

The second verse has a quote from something I read about Tammy Wynette. I really fell for Tammy about a year ago. I love the sort of tongue-and-cheek melodrama of her songs. I read that when she left her first husband to pursue a career in music, he told her ‘dream on, baby.’ Years later, after she was famous, he attended one of her shows and asked for her autograph. She signed it ‘dream on, baby.’
Last ditch desperate, like a makeshift siphon

Japanese Breakfast described in an interview for NPR how she wanted to describe “that really ugly moment when you try to do something sexually wild to save a relationship, only to make it more painfully apparent that it’s not going to work.”

Siphons are often used as a method to save ships from sinking by pulling water out of it. In essence, Japanese Breakfast’s relationship is a sinking ship that she is desperately trying to remove water from. However, she does not have the proper tools to save it and therefore must improvise–through desperate sex.

Pump and run, pump and run
 Pump and run, pump and run

There are a few ways to interpret these lyrics. The “pump” could refer to the sexual action of giving head. “Pump” could also mean filling up the car with gas. “Run” could refer to how she will run away–more like drive away–from the man who she is in a relationship with.

You gave road head on a turnpike exit
 Going home, going home

An image referencing “Brackish Water”, which she wrote for her previous band Little Big League:

Giving road head on the turnpike
And I called it off when I saw what I’d become
I was holes and shape

song.title: Slide Tackle

annotations: Slide tackling my mind

“Slide Tackle” is a term used in soccer, which Michelle stated she played once in the third grade, and her team was the only team that did not score a goal the whole year.

For Michelle, idea of “slide tackle” was like battling or wrestling with a void in your brain, grappling with your mind to force it into submission to feel joy. Translating a physical move metaphorically was funny for Michelle to think about, like literally slide tackling one’s brain into submitting it to enjoy itself. (from Sterogum)

Savage Good Boy Lyrics[Intro]
I want to be your man
I want to be your s-

[Verse 1]
I want to be your man
I want to be your savage good boy
I want to take care of you

[Verse 2]
When everybody's gone
Want you to be the one that I come home to
The one that's up waiting
[Chorus 1]

And we will be so wealthy, I'm absolved from questioning

And as you rear our children, know it's the necessary strain
They're the stakes in a race to liveSee Japanese Breakfast LiveGet tickets as low as $55You might also like3Embed

description.plain:
Michelle Zauner said “Savage Good Boy came from a headline I read about billionaires buying bunkers. I was interested in examining that specific type of villainy, and I found myself adopting the perspective of a rich man coaxing a young woman to come live with him underground, attempting to rationalize his almost impossible share of greed and miserliness. ”

Writing from the perspective of a breadwinner seems to be a recurrent theme in Zauner’s work. In her songs ‘Bread’ and ‘Day 12’, she addressed other storylines where a man is trying to provide for a woman.

body.plain:
Michelle Zauner said “Savage Good Boy came from a headline I read about billionaires buying bunkers. I was interested in examining that specific type of villainy, and I found myself adopting the perspective of a rich man coaxing a young woman to come live with him underground, attempting to rationalize his almost impossible share of greed and miserliness. ”

Writing from the perspective of a breadwinner seems to be a recurrent theme in Zauner’s work. In her songs ‘Bread’ and ‘Day 12’, she addressed other storylines where a man is trying to provide for a woman.

annotations:
When everybody’s gone
 Want you to be the one that I come home to
 The one that’s up waiting
In an interview Michelle Zauner did with Nylon magazine, Savage Good Boy was called  a fizzy ode to her husband a bandmate, Peter Bradley.

I’ve got a five year plan
 I’ve got a pension and six condos
 A billion-dollar bunker for two

In the music video release Q&A with video co-star Michael Imperioli,of Sopranos fame, Michelle Zauner and Michael talked about the morally-gray status of the Sopranos characters, and her idea of exploring different types of villains and anti-heroes.

[Savage Good Boy is] based on a headline that I read about billion dollar bunkers, [that] billionaires were buying up bunkers. And that was this, like, very menacing thing of our times, and how representative of class disparity that was, and how we use wealth to protect ourselves. [on Michael’s character] I was interested in exploring this perspective of a billionaire who has rationalized this hoarding of wealth on such a high level…Shows like the Sopranos have inspired me so much, because I think what makes villainy really menacing is you can see parts of yourself in a villain. They’re human, they’re parts of being human that are exacerbated to lean towards a certain way.”

The Woman That Loves You Lyrics[Verse 1]
You're embarrassing me
With a postponed marriage and a stalled-out car
Then you leave me in the back with half a window rolled down
Like a dog, like a dog in the summer heat

[Chorus]
Don't you think, don't you think
You should try to do as little harm as you can
To the woman that loves you?
[Verse 2]
Oh, we'll stay
Oh, we'll stay together
For the weekend, honey
The weekend, babe
Me and you, frosted blue
But we're gazing out for better things

[Chorus]
You should try to do as little harm as you can
To the woman that loves you
You should try to do as little harm as you can

annotatable.title: The Woman That Loves You

annotations: [Verse 2]
Continuing on with the theme of the first verse, they keep dragging on this relationship, but “gazing” out of the window of the car, which is a metaphor for their relationship, for a better one.

You’re embarrassing me
 With a postponed marriage and a stalled-out car
 Then you leave me in the back with half a window rolled down

This album, along with her entire project name of “Japanese Breakfast” deals with the juxtaposition of Asian and American culture. Here she is alluding to her Asian culture, which idealizes marriage, by saying that he is postponing marrying her and it is in turn embarrassing for her. This “stalled out car” is a metaphor for their relationship. She is saying he is postponing marrying her and dragging on their relationship with no intent for something more. He is also leaving her in the back of this relationship by keeping her in the background of it, where she doesn’t feel important. “Half a window [is] rolled down” and it is making her feel ignored in the relationship and not giving her room to breathe.
